case_vignette: A 74-year-old man with a history of type II diabetes and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden-onset, painless vision loss in his left eye. He describes the feeling as if things went black in his left eye suddenly. His temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 154/94 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves III-XII as intact. The patient is unable to see out of his left eye but has normal vision in his right eye. The rest of his exam including strength, sensation, and gait are unremarkable. An ECG is performed as seen in Figure A and an ultrasound of the eye is performed as seen in Figure B. Fundoscopy is performed as seen in Figure C. A CT scan of the head is currently pending.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly lost vision in my left eye, and it feels like things went black suddenly.
How old are you, and what is your sex?
I am a 74-year-old man.
Do you have any pain in your eye or headache accompanied by this vision loss?
No, I don't have any pain in my eye or headache.
Do you have any known medical conditions such as hypertension, diabetes, or heart disease?
Yes, I have type II diabetes.
Have you noticed any flashes of light or a curtain-like shadow over your field of vision?
No, I haven't noticed any flashes of light or a curtain-like shadow.
Did the vision loss come on gradually or was it an immediate loss?
It was an immediate loss.
Are you currently taking any medications for your diabetes or any other condition?
You didn't provide me with details about specific medications, so I can't answer that question.
I apologize for any confusion. May I know what medications you are currently using to manage your diabetes?
I'm sorry, but I don't have any information about specific medications that I might be taking for my diabetes.
Understood. Has there been any recent trauma to your eye or head?
No, there hasn't been any recent trauma to my eye or head.
Do you have a history of smoking or any cardiovascular problems?
Yes, I have a 40 pack-year smoking history.
Have you experienced any recent changes in your overall health, such as sudden weight loss, fatigue, or loss of appetite?
The vignette doesn't mention any changes like that, so I can't say if I've experienced them.
Is there a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA) in your family?
The vignette doesn't provide any information about my family history, so I can't answer that.
Have you had any previous episodes of visual disturbances in either eye before this incident?
No, this is the first time this has happened.

Final Diagnosis: Sudden painless loss of vision in one eye in an elderly patient with type II diabetes and a significant smoking history is highly suggestive of an ocular vascular event, such as arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) or non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION), possible due to a central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Immediate referral to an ophthalmologist is necessary for further evaluation and management.
